author: Kallol Bhattacherjee
text:
Pakistan High Commissioner Abdul Basit (centre) with Environment Minister Prakash Javadekar at the Pakistan Day celebrations in New Delhi on Wednesday.— PHOTO: PTI

There was an unexpected moment during the celebration of National Day of Pakistan on Wednesday when Pakistan High Commissioner Abdul Basit praised “China-Pakistan Economic Corridor” as a sign of regional cooperation. Minister for Environment Prakash Javadekar represented the government at the event as the chief guest.

In his brief speech, Mr. Basit paid tribute to Pakistan and its commitment to support regional cooperation. “Pakistan is a developing country and China is building a corridor across Pakistan which will help in our development process,” he said.

The economic corridor is controversial in India since it passes through Pakistan-occupied Kashmir.

The presence of Mr. Javadekar at the event was viewed as a mood-builder for the expected summit-level meeting between Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his Pakistan counterpart Nawaz Sharif in Washington DC on the sidelines of the Nuclear Security Summit.

However, Mr. Javadekar’s presence was described by Congress leader Mani Shankar Aiyar as a “token representation” since he did not address the gathering following the speech by Mr. Basit.

Diplomats present at the event told The Hindu that the mention of the corridor by the High Commissioner added to the buzz around the event, which was already in focus after Minister of State for Home Affairs Jitendra Singh dropped out at the last moment.
title: In Javadekar’s presence, Basit lauds controversial China corridor
